page1_1.title: Nanliao Overview
page1_1.content: Welcome to Nanliao Village, a place with deep cultural roots and more than 400 years of history. Since the 17th century, Penghu has been an important maritime hub. It was once targeted by the Dutch East India Company as their gateway to China but was soon driven out by the Ming Dynasty. After the First Sino-Japanese War in 1895, Penghu was ceded to Japan under the Treaty of Shimonoseki and later entered a period of modernization. Unlike urban areas, Nanliao is a traditional farming-and-fishing village where people rely on the land, water sources, and the sea. The coral-stone walls, old houses, and traditional wells seen throughout the village reflect the lives of early settlers. These unique cultural landscapes have made Nanliao one of the world's Top 100 Green Destinations. Through Nanliao‚Äôs stories, we hope you can discover the vibrant and diverse culture of Penghu.

page1_2.title: Nanliao Water Source
page1_2.content: We are now standing on Nanliao‚Äôs main road, known locally as 'Zhongzheng Road'. Beneath this road lies the village‚Äôs most important historical waterway. The water originated from the red-soil hills in the east and flowed northwest toward Kuibei Harbor, serving as the main freshwater supply for villagers. People used the waterway for washing clothes, preparing fish, and even building fish ovens. The road‚Äôs shape today still follows the original water channel. The waterway, about 1.3 km long, once flowed year-round and symbolized Nanliao‚Äôs abundant groundwater, helping the village thrive. It is said that Nanliao‚Äôs No. 1 Well was dug here under the guidance of Baosheng Emperor, providing a stable water source for the residents.

page1_3.title: Origin Unfinished
page1_3.content: Here we arrive at Nanliao‚Äôs No. 1 Well, nearly 400 years old. In 2024, the government renovated the surrounding area to highlight the theme of water resources. The site includes art installations showing early villagers‚Äô daily activities, such as 'Origin Unfinished' and 'Jumping into the Well'. The well is built with coral stones, and its guardrails were traditionally constructed by women, showcasing local craftsmanship. Coral stones are also provided for visitors to try stacking, giving you a hands-on experience of building a well.

page1_4.title: Well Jumping Kids
page1_4.content: This sculpture shows how children in the past would pull their pants halfway down and eagerly jump into the well to cool off during summer. Since parents believed the sea was dangerous, kids often played in wells instead. The rough coral-stone walls made it easier to climb and relatively safe. The underwear they wore was made from 22 kg flour bags provided during U.S. aid programs‚Äîa symbol of better-off families at the time.

page1_5.title: Nanliao Walking Route
page1_5.content: Nanliao‚Äôs water-related sites are spread across the village. We recommend starting from Well No. 1, then heading east along the main road. You will pass Xu Fan Old House, the Zhao Ancestral Temple, the Floating Ball Turtle, and clusters of old houses. Continue to the 'Cow Dung Pit', which demonstrates traditional cow-dung cake making, and finish at the Hongtougou water source. On the return trip, you can visit four historic wells in the village and collect stamps on your 'Water Memory' postcard.

page2.title: Fuji Fish Oven
page2.content: Built in 1959 by Dai Fuji, the fish oven consists of three main parts: the stove, chimney, and brine tank. Summer is the season for sardines (locally called 'stinky fish'), and villagers processed them into dried fish for export to Taiwan and Japan. To help preserve this traditional craft, the community renovated the site in 2012 with the owner's permission, restoring its original appearance.

page3.title: Coral Stone Tree House
page3.content: In the early Republic era, three families lived in this old house. The main room was run by a Chinese medicine shop owned by people from Qingluo. When villagers felt unwell, they would consult Baosheng Emperor, draw a healing fortune, and prepare the prescribed herbal remedies here. The east room was used for private schooling, and the west room housed a barbershop. In 2013, international volunteers helped renovate and decorate the house, turning it into a historical hideaway.

page4.title: Xu Fan Old House
page4.content: Built during the Xianfeng era (1851‚Äì1861), this traditional house features a single structure with four side rooms. It includes the main building, side rooms, a pavilion area, and a deep well. The coral-stone walls were plastered using Penghu‚Äôs traditional techniques. In 1935, Xu Fan renovated the house. As a Taoist practitioner of the L√ºshan school, he became a founding ritual master of Baoning Temple. The Penghu County Cultural Bureau recognized the house as a historic building for its religious and artistic value.

page5.title: Turning Floats
page5.content: Located at Penghu‚Äôs northeast, Nanliao collects large amounts of drifted marine waste brought by monsoon winds. Retired local Zhao Changshou began cleaning beaches and collecting usable fishing floats. After careful sorting and arranging, he transformed them into a meaningful environmental installation.

page6.title: Small Farmers Market
page6.content: Nanliao is a traditional farming village. Spring brings corn; summer and autumn produce peanuts, sweet potatoes, pumpkins, and gourds; and winter grows cabbage, turnip, broccoli, and carrots. In 2014, with the owner's consent, the community transformed this space into a market area where villagers sell their produce and seafood from the intertidal zone, promoting toxin-free farming and reduced food carbon footprints.

page7.title: Chicken-Dog Park
page7.content: Life in early Penghu was harsh. During the Winter Solstice festival, children shaped dough made from rice flour into animals‚Äîcows, sheep, pigs, chickens, ducks, dogs‚Äîas offerings to pray for blessings and a prosperous harvest. These dough figures, called 'Chicken-Dog', later became children‚Äôs snacks and toys. To preserve this tradition, the Penghu County Government built Chicken-Dog Park as a cultural landmark.

page8.title: Zhao Ancestral Temple
page8.content: In 1949, the military stationed troops here. When Taiwan Television began broadcasting, the village gathered here to watch the only black-and-white TV. Soldiers practiced dances, merchants performed shows, and outdoor movies were screened‚Äîmaking the area the liveliest place in the village. After the military left, a fish oven was built here, creating bustling crowds again. Today, it serves as a place for Zhao descendants to honor their ancestors.

page9.title: Zhao Old House Cluster
page9.content: This cluster of old houses, located between numbers 77 and 95, belongs to the Zhao family. The traditional appearance has been preserved, and community cleanup efforts highlight the peaceful and classical atmosphere. Standing in the narrow lane ('Descendant Alley'), you can feel the cool breeze that villagers often enjoyed as a place to rest and calm their minds.

page10.title: Coral Stone Walls
page10.content: Coral-stone walls, commonly known as 'residential walls', are unique structures in Penghu built to withstand strong northeast winds. Coral was collected during low tide using long hooks and lever techniques, then transported by boats and ox carts. Stones were stacked to build vegetable gardens or houses. Large building stones had to weather for over two years before use. Today, coral harvesting is prohibited to protect marine resources.

page11.title: Cow Dung Pit
page11.content: The Cow Dung Pit recreation area restores the traditional rural lifestyle. In 2013, with the landowner‚Äôs permission and support from the Rural Regeneration Program, the community cleared the overgrown land and recreated the original environment where villagers once stepped on cow dung and made cow-dung cakes‚Äîturning it into an educational experience site.

page12.title: One-Day Farmer
page12.content: Nanliao has extensive farmland stretching east to Guoye, west to Huxi and Hudong, north to Beiliao, and south to Jianshan. Large fields outside the village are called 'mountains', while small gardens next to homes are called 'home plots'. Here you can imagine scenes of early farming life‚Äîbending down to plant crops, plowing with cattle, stacking coral stones, weaving grass, and roasting sweet potatoes. Pick up a handful of soil and feel the warmth and energy of the land.

page13.title: Experience Farm
page13.content: Farm owner Zhao Jiaxie practices organic and eco-friendly farming. In 2014, the farm was officially certified organic. Besides producing organic vegetables, the farm offers tours and hands-on farming experiences, aiming toward edible landscapes and sustainable agriculture.

page14.title: Masked Women
page14.content: Penghu‚Äôs traditional 'face-wrapping cloth' was used by women working in the fields or at sea to protect themselves from the hot sun, strong northeast winds, and salt spray. Different regions had different wrapping styles. The local style used a square cloth plus a towel to cover the face, giving rise to the name 'Masked Women'. Because of its cultural significance, it is listed as an intangible cultural heritage.

page15.title: Baosheng Avenue
page15.content: This road connects Nanliao and Beiliao, and both villages worship Baosheng Emperor. In the past, when people fell ill or faced difficulties, they prayed for healing or guidance by drawing divine lots. The mural wall here was created to preserve this tradition. The colors‚Äîyellow, blue, red, green, white, and black‚Äîcome from temple symbolism and the Five Battalions system, representing protection from all directions and the colors used in divine banners.
